Jon  has been a scenic carpenter, production electrician, Off-Broadway TD and ATD in  New York for over twenty years. Jon received his BFA in Design/Illustration  from Marywood College. Jon co-teaches the first year scenery  stagecraft class.        Ella Bromblin   Budget Director. After years of studying mathematics at Odessa  University in Ukraine, Ella decided to find herself closer to the arts and  began working as a budget director at TSOA.   Ella also takes photos of all the Graduate Acting / Dance / Design  productions. Ella has been working at  NYU for over 25 years.          Ellie Bye   Props Master. During her first week living in NYC, Ellie  achieved a life long dream: dressing the Bergdorf Goodman and Van Cleef &  Arpel windows for Fashion's Night Out. Ellie has worked in the prop departments  at Williamstown Theatre Festival, The Santa Fe Opera, The Public Theater, and  The Bucks County Playhouse. Her artisan work has been seen at venues like  Manhattan Theater Club, New World Stages, and The Paper Mill Playhouse. TV  credits include MTV and Saturday Night Live. Ellie  co-teaches the first year scenery stagecraft class. BFA  Theatrical Production and Set Design from Pennsylvania State University.           Daun Fallon   Costume Shop Manager.   After receiving a BA in Costume Design from the University of California,  Santa Barbara, Daun spent 10 years working as a draper for several theaters  including the Denver Center and the Santa Fe Opera. Daun also spent more  than a decade heading the design department at a NYC based doll company  (creating miniature costumes) before returning to the theatre. Daun co-teaches  the costume stagecraft class with Maggie Raywood.          David Fry Charge Scenic Artist.  David has been the scenic artist at the University of Cincinnati CCM and the  Opera Theatre of Lucca, Italy, as well as “Playing With Fire” the national  touring exhibition of Julie Taymor’s designs. David was the 2002 USITT Exekiel  Award of Distinction recipient for Scenic Craft, and his work has been featured  on the cover of Stage Directions trade magazine. He has a BFA from the  University of Cincinnati and is an accomplished exhibited oil painter.   Kate Gibson Producing Coordinator. Most recently Kate has coordinated hundreds of productions and events for The Clarice Smith Performing Arts Center at the University of Maryland, College Park. She is also the founding Production Manager for the Charm City Fringe Festival in her native Baltimore. A member of Actors' Equity Association, Kate has dozens of management and performance credits spanning New York, Regional Theatre, and National/International Tours. B.Mus. Shenandoah Conservatory in Music and Theatre, M.A. NYU/Steinhardt in Musical Theatre Performance.      Chris Girard   Master Carpenter. After receiving his MA in Fine Art and Art History from the Sorbonne, Paris, Chris moved from  France to the US. He began working at NYU in 2003 as a freelance carpenter, scenic painter, and electrician. Following 2 years working as a gallery guide  at the Guggenheim, Chris became the Master Carpenter at NYU. In addition, he has worked in the design and building of window displays for brands such as Versace, Dolce & Gabbana,  and Bloomingdales.       Erik Grathwohl Supervisor of Second Year Production. Erik has been a scenic designer, dramaturg, scenic  carpenter, production electrician, and Off-Broadway TD and ATD in New York  for seven years. He also worked for two years as a lighting designer for an NJ-based national production company. Erik received his BFA in Scenic and  Technical production from Carnegie Mellon, and his MFA in Dramaturgy from Columbia University. Erik co-teaches the first year scenery stagecraft class.        Megan Dawson Jaffe   First Hand/Stitcher. Megan received her MFA in Costume Construction from Boston University in 2003, and promptly moved to  New York. Before coming to NYU, she worked at Carelli Costumes on various Broadway and off-Broadway productions. Other technical credits include The  Court Theatre at the University of Chicago, American Players Theatre, and Glimmerglass Opera. Megan's life outside of NYU includes freelance projects  that range from haunted houses to drag queens to ecclesiastic wear.          Ann Mathews Director of Production.   Ann has supervised several hundred graduate productions at TSOA. She is a recipient of the NYU Distinguished  Administrator of the Year award. Ann has worked in theatres from Alaska to  Alabama, including such venues as the Arena Stage, Yale Repertory Theatre,  Playwrights Horizon, and the Intiman, Seattle Rep and Empty Space theatres in  Seattle. She holds a BA in Theatre from the University of Washington and an MA  in Religion from the Claremont School of Theology.          Margaret Raywood Costume Director. Please click above to see her faculty biography.          Katherine Takacs   Associate Technical Director. Katie graduated from  the University of Arizona with her BFA in Technical Theater, emphasis in Technical  Direction and Scene Design in 2008. She worked at Trinity Repertory Company as  a carpenter and welder for two years, and was the Technical Director for the  Brown/Trinity Rep MFA Program. Katie was the Technical Director at Rattlestick  Playwrights' Theatre, working on such productions as underneathmybed, The  Hallway Trilogy, and Asuncion, amongst many others. She also worked  as a freelance carpenter at various Off - Broadway theaters, before beginning her  association with Theatrical Production.   Katie co-teaches the first year scenery stagecraft class.          Mike Voytko   Lighting and Sound Supervisor.  Previous work includes: Resident Lighting Designer, Boheme Opera NJ; Lighting  Coordinator, Opera Co. of Philadelphia; Master Electrician, Wilma Theater and  Philadelphia Theatre Co.; Assistant Master Electrician, Williamstown Theatre  Festival.        Lydia Witt   Stitcher/Wardrobe. Production Center: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        Production Center  NYU boasts one of the largest filmmaking facilities on the Eastern Seaboard, serving the needs of both our Undergraduate and Graduate film and video students. The facility is run by 11 full-time staff members and over 50 technical assistants that are both technically and professionally trained in many technical and aesthetic aspects of film production, including: film planning and production, equipment operation, equipment maintenance and repair.    The Production Center supports every aspect of the well-over 4,500 student projects shot every year, with technical seminars, industry-professional equipment, film stock and supplies, equipment repair services, and additional support for planning and development of student films. The equipment packages vary by level of study (fundamental through advanced/thesis), and are available to students enrolled in production courses. the production center consists of 5 areas which include the Advanced and Fundamental Equipment Areas, Repair Shop, Equipment Reservations Office, and the Production Office, which provides the students with the supplies and resources needed to produce a film or video. Dolan Music Recording Studio , a 7,500 square foot multifunctional teaching, recording, and research space designed by Gensler and the Walters-Storyk Design Group. One of the most technologically advanced audio teaching facilities in the United States, the new spaces greatly enhance the 10 existing studios which house the Music Technology program. The studio is located on the sixth floor of 35 West 4th Street.       Audio Slideshow and Studio Blueprint       About the Music Technology Program    Music Technology at NYU Steinhardt is a leading and internationally recognized program in music, sound and audio technology. Students prepare for successful careers in sound engineering, computer music, audio-visual production and post-production, mastering, scoring for film and multimedia, audio for games, software development, and multimedia production.    Students study with premier faculty in New York City, the heart of the nation's new media and music industries, and join an active community of scholars, artists and engineers exploring the cutting edge of technology and music.    As part of a large and active department, the Music Technology program emphasizes the integration of musical and technical skills. Music Technology maintains a close alliance with the NYU Performance and Composition programs, encouraging collaborations that explore new relationships between experimental and traditional approaches to music. In addition, the Music Technology program offers an extensive internship program at major recording studios, new-media web-related companies, music-scoring houses and other music industry enterprises.    Students may earn a Bachelor of Music degree in Music Technology, a Master of Music degree in Music Technology, or a Doctor of Philosophy in Music Technology. Students are also encouraged to take advantage of special courses offered abroad and during the Summer .    State-of-the-art facilities include 10 fully equipped recording and computer music studios, listening rooms and research labs where over 40 Music Technology specialization courses are taught.       Dr. Kenneth J. Peacock, Ph.D. Professor of Music Director, Music Technology Program.
